thread.title: Rockets Top Warriors 104-100 in NBA Cup Clash Amid Curry's Injury Concerns - SSBCrack News
thread.title_full: Rockets Top Warriors 104-100 in NBA Cup Clash Amid Curry's Injury Concerns - SSBCrack News

author: News Desk
title: Rockets Top Warriors 104-100 in NBA Cup Clash Amid Curry's Injury Concerns - SSBCrack News
text:
In a tightly contested matchup at Chase Center, the Houston Rockets managed to secure a 104-100 victory over the Golden State Warriors, despite the absence of star player Kevin Durant. Reed Sheppard emerged as the standout performer, leading all scorers with an impressive 31 points. However, the game took a critical turn when Stephen Curry exited with an injury with just 35 seconds left, casting a shadow over the outcome and raising questions about his availability going forward.
One of the most noteworthy aspects of the game was the Rockets’ defensive strategy against Curry. The Rockets consistently guarded him with elite on-ball defenders, Amen Thompson and Josh Okogie. This aggressive approach, combined with a tendency to blitz Curry during pick-and-roll scenarios, limited his effectiveness significantly. Curry finished the game with only 14 points on 4-of-13 shooting, complemented by an uncharacteristic seven turnovers. Notably, his limited attempts—just 13 shots compared to his usual average of nearly 20—highlighted the challenges he faced against Houston’s defense.
Moreover, the Rockets cleverly placed Curry in multiple ball-screen actions on defense, draining his energy on that end of the court. The officiating also played a critical role; a challenged call where Thompson initially received an offensive foul designation was overturned, while a contested charge against Curry went unchallenged by officials. Such moments illustrated the struggle Curry faced not just against the Rockets but also with the referees during the contest.
On the other side of the court, Draymond Green outshone Alperen Sengun in their matchup. While Sengun posted respectable numbers with 16 points, six rebounds, and six assists, Green provided a more impactful presence with 12 points, eight rebounds, and eight assists. Green’s defensive prowess forced Sengun into a challenging shooting night, as he managed just 7-of-18 from the field. The disparity in their plus-minus ratings—Green at plus-11 compared to Sengun’s minus-16—further illustrated Green’s dominance in this matchup, despite dealing with a minor foot issue.
The game also shed light on an emerging concern for the Warriors; prolonged offensive droughts. In the third quarter, the Warriors endured a painful 4:53 stretch without a field goal, managing to score only two points during that time. This led the Rockets to capitalize with a 12-2 run that significantly altered the momentum of the game. Although the Warriors are known for their prolific three-point shooting, ranked second in attempts per game, their dependency on outside shots may have hindered their ability to drive toward the basket during crucial moments. Notably, veteran guard Jimmy Butler, significantly placed to help reduce the scoring lull, managed just one shot after entering the game for the final minutes of the drought, raising questions about the team’s offensive adjustments in critical situations.
As the season progresses, both teams will reflect on this matchup, with Houston celebrating a crucial win and Golden State searching for solutions to bolster their performance moving forward, especially in light of Curry’s injury status.
